elements.text:
The Graphics workplace is where you make the
sprites for your carts. As with the other
workspaces there is a hamburger menu and tabs
along the top of your screen.

On the center of the page is the Sprite Editor, 
where you draw any sprites for your carts.
On the bottom-left of the screen shows your pixel
co-ordinates, x across and y down. This means
0,0 is the top-left pixel of your sprite, not the
bottom left as some may expect

On the right-hand side of the screen is the 
graphics menu, with all the tools you need to 
make your sprites.

At the top is the color palette, with two tabs.
The first tab shows all 64 colors that you have 
on your palette, however by default there are 
only 33. The second shows the first 32 colors in
your palette.
In each tab you can click a color to select it.

Below the palette is the toolbar, with each 
selectable brush type on it.

Pencil: a simple tool that fills one tile with
your selected color wherever your cursor is.
Paintbrush: when selected, the brush editor is
brought up below it.
Line: draws a straight line from the point you
start holding down click to the point you release.
Shapes: draw their respective shape's outline,
when holding CTRL they are filled in.
Bucket: fill the clicked area with a color.
Stamp: pastes what is copied to your clipboard in,
making repeating patterns easier.
Marquee: draws a region that limits the area
other tools work, click once to remove area.
Using the arrow keys moves the selected pixels
around, so you can adjust them.
Pan: pans the camera to move around your sprite

The paintbrush editor appears below the toolbar
while the paintbrush tool is selected, allowing
for customization of the tool. On the left is
the pattern display, with two rows to its right.
The top row shows brush size, from one pixel to
eight, along with horizontal and diagonal lines.
The bottom row is the patterns, which will act as
a repeating mask over your brush, cutting
sections out of it - this is useful for shading
sprites.
Whatever is selected here will display as a
looping pattern on the pattern display.

Lastly is the sprite panel. This shows an 8x8
grid of all your sprites, with 4 tabs - meaning
256 sprites total.
Above the sprite panel is the middle 16x16
of the selected sprite, followed by it's index,
used in multiple commands such as spr() to
identify what sprite you are using.
After the index is the sprite size, allowing you
to adjust your canvas size, up to 9000x9000
pixels for one sprite. In between the two scales
is the lock button, which will freeze the aspect
ratio, meaning when you change one axis the other
axis will be the same relative size.
Lastly, there are the 8 sprite flags, from 0 to
7, allowing for you to give different sprites
flags which you can make have their own meanings,
such as 'enemy' or 'floor'.

General controls:
The arrow keys scroll your sprite, wrapping it
around the edges of your canvas
Press 'f' to flip your sprite horizontally
Press 'v' to flip your sprite vertically
